author: @carlabest1257
text: What you are saying about global variables being accessible anywhere is simply not true.  Just about all videos on python are misleading regarding the scoping rules that define so called global variables.   One module cannot "see" the global variables in another module without importing that global variable.  That fact that you need to import that global variable from module A does not eliminate the need for modules B,C,and D to import that global variable.   Doesn't sound like a global variable to me.   Sounds like a module variable at best.  Just one more crazy quirk that makes python difficult to use and introduces strange quirky errors.

author: @azzam9930
text: +1 nonlocal variables , used inside a nested function .  Python 3 introduced the nonlocal keyword that allows you to assign to variables in an outer, but non-global, scope. An example will illustrate what I mean. msg is declared in the outside function and assigned the value "Outside!". Then, in the inside function, the value "Inside!" is assigned to it. https://www.smallsurething.com/a-quick-guide-to-nonlocal-in-python-3/

author: @djleisheng
text: What would be an example of why you would ever want to modify a variable this way? Isn't it simpler to just pass it as a parameter and return it?  def example(x):     x += 5     return x  x = 6  x = example(x)  # prints out 11  I feel like there's a good reason professors say not to use global variables.  If you're building a big project, namespaces are a better way to go to avoid duplicate definitions, or even a class called GlobalVariables would probably be better.  Then again, it is part of the language construct, so maybe it has applications I haven't thought of.

author: @pythonprogrammer6938
text: # Heres an example of Global variables, copy it into idle, it will count up to the number you input...  import time # Allows you to play with time in python.  my_number = int(input("What do you want to count up to? ")) # Let you input a number  number_counting_up = 0 # Give number_counting_up the value of 0  def rerun_counter (): # Define rerun_counter:     counter ()        # Run the modual called counter  def counter ():                                       # Define counter     if  number_counting_up >= my_number - 1:          # If number_counting_up is MORE THAN OR EQUAL TO my_number -1 (-1 means that number but with 1 taken away from it)         print ("It has been", my_number , "seconds!") # Print it has been (How ever many seconds you inputed) seconds.         quit ()                                       # Quit the Application          elif number_counting_up != my_number: # Or if number_counting_up is NOT EQUAL TO my_number:         number_counting_up += 1           # Add 1 to number_counting_up         global number_counting_up         # Make number_counting_up a global command (So it can be used outside of the if statement)         print (number_counting_up)        # Print the number that number_counting_up is currently on         time.sleep (1)                    # Wait a second         rerun_counter ()                  # Run the program called rerun_counter  counter () # This makes the if statement called counter run.    # sentdex is boss!
